posts.title: Introducing the Exercism blog
posts.marketing_copy: Each day Exercism gets hundreds of new users, thousands of new submissions, and dozens of improvements across its language tracks and product, but many people have no idea how much is going on or how active the site is. Today we're launching our new blog in order to change that!

posts.title: Exercism in 2019
posts.marketing_copy: We're super excited about all that we have planned for this year. Read on to learn about our focuses and plans for Exercism in 2019 including reducing friction for mentors, static analysis, improved curriculums and the launching of this blog!

posts.title: What happens if my mentor disappears?
posts.marketing_copy: Sometimes you're working away improving an exercise and your mentor disappers. Up until now, that's been a big problem but this week we've made some big strides forward. Learn more about how we're dealing with it moving forward.

posts.title: An interview with Erik Schierboom
posts.marketing_copy: We talk to Erik Schierboom about functional programming, maintaining the C#, F# and Scala tracks, and our plans for automated static analysis of Exercism solutions.

posts.title: We've relaunched community comments
posts.marketing_copy: One consequence of adding mentoring to Exercism last year was the removal of casual commenting. We've now added that back. Read on to learn more.

posts.title: An interview with Ryan Potts
posts.marketing_copy: Ryan Potts talks to us about how he got into Delphi, the things he's learnt from being a contributor to Exercism, and his experiences of programming in industries that are still offline.

posts.title: The Track Anatomy Project
posts.marketing_copy: Welcome to The Track Anatomy Project - an initiative to determine how Exercism tracks can best provide structure for learners and support for mentors.

posts.title: The Automated Mentoring Support Project
posts.marketing_copy: Over the next few months we are going to be developing a framework that uses static analysis to automatically analysis users' solutions, automatically approve solutions that are idiomatic, and provide feedback for commonly-seen improvements. Read on to learn about the project.

posts.title: An interview with Meade Kincke
posts.marketing_copy: Katrina talks to Meade Kicke about the Rust compiler, a GUI that uses scientific colourspaces to determine the colour of beer, and his book 'A Practical Guide To Rust'.

posts.title: Mozilla awards Exercism an Open Source Support Award
posts.marketing_copy: Mozilla has awarded Exercism an Open Source Support Award to help support our Automated Mentoring Support Project - using static analysis to automatically approve solutions that are idiomatic, and provide feedback for commonly-seen improvements.

posts.title: Inspiring kids to code with Clever Tykes
posts.marketing_copy: Meet Code-it Cody, a computer whizz who starts coding at school - part of the Clever Tykes of storybooks and resources which inspire children to develop positive, resourceful and creative behaviour.

posts.title: Coding Intentionally in Bash Grains
posts.marketing_copy: Ryan Palo explores the concepts of 'intentional coding' and 'design intent' in this excellent walkthrough of the Grains exercise in Bash. Thinking of ways to solve a problem is easy- designing one that communicates your thought process and goals to others is the hard part.

posts.title: Unicode matching in Elixir
posts.marketing_copy: Percy Grunwald explores unicode matching in Elixir and shows how a trivial exercise can teach useful real-world lessons about handling Unicode in Elixir.

posts.title: Concurrency and Parallelism in Elixir
posts.marketing_copy: Percy Grunwald explores concurrency and parallelism in Elixir and shows how a trivial exercise can teach useful real-world lessons about parallel and concurrent computation in Elixir vs other popular languages.

posts.title: What's next for Exercism?
posts.marketing_copy: Where has Exercism got to? What are we focussing on next? Learn about our plans for the next 12 months and where we'll be focussing our energy.

posts.title: Redesigning tracks in partnership with The University of Chicago and The Sloan Foundation
posts.marketing_copy: We're excited to announce a project in partnership with The University of Chicago, funded by The Sloan Foundation, in which we're going to be rethinking Exercism's tracks from the ground up.

posts.title: Independent Mode has been renamed to Practice Mode
posts.marketing_copy: We've renamed Independent Mode to Practice Mode. Learn more about why in this post.

posts.title: Dealing with oversubscribed tracks
posts.marketing_copy: Oversubscribed tracks is a big problem for Exercism. This blog post outlines some short-term fixes we're putting in place to try and help with the problem.

posts.title: Announcing Exercism Research
posts.marketing_copy: We're launching Exercism Research - a new space to host experiments to help us understand how people learn new programming languages.

posts.title: Was V2 worth the effort?
posts.marketing_copy: As we move towards Exercism V3, I wanted to expore the impact that V2 had and analyse whether it was worth the effort that the community put in.

posts.title: Call for Track Maintainers
posts.marketing_copy: We're looking for some new Track Maintainers to help us on our journey to Exercism version 3. If you're interested in helping out, please read on!

posts.title: Sorry for the wait
posts.marketing_copy: Our community is hard at work building Exercism v3, which means mentoring is quite a bit slower than normal. Read to learn more

posts.title: Exercism has moved to exercism.org
posts.marketing_copy: Exercism has a new home! With the launch of v3 we've moved from exercism.io to exercism.org. Read on to learn more!

posts.title: Exercism v3 has launched
posts.marketing_copy: The brand new version of Exercism has launched. Hear our co-founders' thoughts and check some FAQs inside.

posts.title: Analyzers, Representers & Syllabuses - What's new in Exercism?
posts.marketing_copy: Angelika looks at the big changes to Exercism in version 3 and what they were designed to fix. She takes a walk through the problems in v2 and new features and technology, including analyzers, respresenters, the new Learning Exercises and syllabuses.

posts.title: Exercism is now the official Go Mentoring Platform
posts.marketing_copy: Exercism is now the official Go Mentoring Platform for the Go Developer Network and GoBridge. We're really excited to help more developers fall in love with Go and proud to be in partnership with The Bridge Foundary

posts.title: Introducing the "Community" tab
posts.marketing_copy: We're introducing forums, swag, community stories and a whole Dig Deeper section to exercises. Read to learn more!

posts.title: It's time to Dig Deeper!
posts.marketing_copy: Solving an exercise on Exercism is just the start! The real value is unlocked by what comes next - exploring other's solutions, getting mentored, and our new feature - the Dig Deeper tab.

posts.title: Introducing Representers
posts.marketing_copy: Over the last few weeks we've been rolling out the second part our automated feedback strategy - Representers.  Watch to learn what they are, how they work, and why they're useful!

posts.title: Freeing our maintainers
posts.marketing_copy: We're spending a few months redesigning our volunteering model and giving our key volunteers a break from the work of reviewing community contributions.

stories.title: Learn to code by telling the story of a program
stories.blurb: Rebecca Mark works for Unison Computing, where her mission is to make learning the Unison programming language as fun and accessible as can be.

stories.title: ABAP & ABAP
stories.blurb: Lars Hvam lives in Copenhagen, Denmark and loves the ABAP programming language. Having put together the ABAP track on Exercism, we caught up with Lars and had a chilled chat about how he ended up in tech.

stories.title: Problem Solving Your Way into being a Tech Lead
stories.blurb: Gabriel Nelle is living in South Germany near Baden-Baden. He’s sharing the apartment with his girlfriend and two cats. He studied to be a teacher for mathematics and German at university in Siegen which he finished in 2008

stories.title: Don't Be Too Productive!
stories.blurb: In this Community Story, Franziska and Jonathan chat about team dynamics, how different people in a business approach collaboration and about how to position yourself in a way to learn to become a programmer.

stories.title: Expeditions, Elixir and Exercism
stories.blurb: In this week's Community Story, Brian and Jonathan take a moment to chat about cross-cultural experience, functional programming and what it was like to move from the American mid-west to Scandinavia.

stories.title: Entrepreneurial by Design
stories.blurb: Are you an entrepreneur looking to dabble in tech? Taiyab sheds some light on ways to see things from the business and product design perspective in this week's Community Story.

stories.title: Prolific Mentor and System Automator
stories.blurb: Negatively labelled a jack-of-all-trades? Maybe it's actually a good thing, especially when mentoring people from diverse backgrounds, programming experience and cultures! Isaac is a self-proclaimed techie and Jack of all trades...amongst many other things!

stories.title: Beating Paralysis and Printing a one-handed Keyboard
stories.blurb: What happens when you think that a door which was open, suddenly closes in your face? Bobbi's story of overcoming a severely debilitating injury to continue his journey of being a programming is remarkable!

stories.title: Becoming a Polyglot Developer
stories.blurb: What is a 'Polyglot', I hear you say...well, according to the dictionary, it's the ability to know several languages! So how do you become a 'Polyglot'? You talk to Erik Schierboom and get the inside track!

stories.title: Conquering Cancer to Accessibility Activism
stories.blurb: What happens when you get life-changing news or information? How do you respond? How do you process? Catch up with DJ to hear how he re-framed his perspective on hearing he'd been diagnosed with cancer.

stories.title: Push Off With Python!
stories.blurb: Every now and then we come across someone who dives into the deep end with learning to program! Carl, also known as 'Meatball' online, started to learn to code using the Python track in Exercism...that is quite the feat, but who doesn't love a challenge!

stories.title: Programmer By Accident!
stories.blurb: It would never have occurred to us that solving exercises in Exercism could actually be a form of therapy for many! The human interaction via mentoring and sense of achievement seems to have a powerful impact that we explore in our latest chat with Thelma!
